examples.en: It’s been long since I stopped eating bacon.
examples.ja: 私がベーコンを食べなくなって久しい。

examples.en: Japanese people have taken peace for granted for so long that they probably can't understand it anymore.
examples.ja: 平和ボケして久しい日本人には、おそらく理解できないだろう。

examples.en: He ate a raw goldfish and has been dead for a long time now.
examples.ja: 彼が生の金魚を食べて死んでから久しい。

meaning_mnemonic: This is a single kanji with しい on the end, meaning it's an adjective. What's the adjective form of <kanji>long time</kanji>? Well, it's <vocabulary>long ago</vocabulary>, or can mean <vocabulary>for a long time</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

<vocabulary>Long ago</vocabulary>, in a galaxy far away, a bunch of prequel movies were ruined by a single character. "<reading>Heesa</reading> (ひさ) the best character!" you hear. Oh no. Heesa here. Get out before Jar Jar Binks gets you! Keep him in the past!

examples.en: I investigated my shortcomings.
examples.ja: 自分の欠点を究明しました。

examples.en: I want to get to the bottom of the cause of the accident.
examples.ja: 事故の原因を究明したいんです。

examples.en: I investigated the weaknesses of aluminum batteries.
examples.ja: アルミ電池の弱点を究明した。

meaning_mnemonic:
If you do <kanji>research</kanji> to <kanji>bright</kanji>en a subject area, you're probably doing some kind of <vocabulary>investigation</vocabulary> that illuminates the unknown.

This word is usually found in academic and scientific contexts, and suggests a thorough investigation meant to ascertain or clarify something.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word, which usually means on'yomi readings from the kanji. You've seen those readings in other compounds, so hopefully you know how to read this one.

examples.en: The test prep is so hard, I'm about to give up.
examples.ja: 試験勉強が難しすぎて、白旗を上げそうだよ。

examples.en: Even though we waved a white flag, they would probably just wipe all of us out anyways.
examples.ja: 白旗をふったところで、アイツらは我々を皆殺しにするつもりですよ。

examples.en: Despite being on a diet, when I saw that delicious looking cake, it made me wave the white flag in my heart.
examples.ja: いくらダイエット中でも、あの美味しそうなケーキを見たら、心の中で白旗を上げちゃったよね。

examples.en: Raising a white flag means surrendering to the enemy.
examples.ja: 白旗を上げるということは、敵に降伏するということだ。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>white</kanji> <kanji>flag</kanji> is a <vocabulary>white flag</vocabulary>. It's one for surrender. I give up! Too many kanji!
reading_mnemonic: You'll have to be careful about this one, as it's actually read with the two kanji's kun'yomi readings put together, making this しろはた.

examples.en: Firstly, I plan to start by expanding my local network of contacts.
examples.ja: まずはローカルの人脈を広げるとこから始めるつもりです。

examples.en: Then, I'm considering starting a business by leveraging this network.
examples.ja: それから、人脈を活かして、何かビジネスをスタートしようと思ってます。

examples.en: Networking is a very important skill for most business people, but it’s especially true for entrepreneurs.
examples.ja: 人脈作りは、ビジネスに関わる殆ど全ての人にとってとても重要なスキルですが、事業家にとっては殊更です。

meaning_mnemonic: Your <kanji>person</kanji> <kanji>vein</kanji>s are all the veins you have going out to all the different people you know. These are your <vocabulary>personal connections</vocabulary>, your <vocabulary>network</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: "It’s tomorrow, but I think we should still cancel our wedding." "You took the words right out of my mouth."
examples.ja: 「もう明日だけど、でも、やっぱり、私たちの結婚式を中止するべきだと思うの。」「僕もそれを言おうと思っていたんだ。」

meaning_mnemonic: If 結婚 is <kanji>marriage</kanji>, then a marriage <kanji>ceremony</kanji> is a <vocabulary>marriage ceremony</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>wedding</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: If you have to push a button to open the doors, can you still call them automatic doors?
examples.ja: 押しボタン式のドアでも、自動ドアって呼ぶのかな。

meaning_mnemonic: If 押し is <kanji>push</kanji>, and a ボタン is a button, then you have yourself a <vocabulary>push button</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as 押す.

examples.en: Please feel free to use the futon in the closet if you wish.
examples.ja: 押入れの布団、良ければ使って下さいね。

meaning_mnemonic: You <kanji>push</kanji> things to make them <kanji>enter</kanji> the <vocabulary>closet</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>cupboard</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is 押し (push the し inside the 押) plus 入れる's reading.

examples.en: Although he is a famous fiction writer, he sometimes self-publishes his books.
examples.ja: 彼は有名な小説家だが、時々自費出版することもあるんだよ。

meaning_mnemonic: If 出版 is <kanji>publishing</kanji>, then the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to publish</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from 出版, so if you know that you know this. Also, it's just the kanji readings too, so no problemo for a person like you, I'm sure.

examples.en: You have to show your ID card to enter the publishing company.
examples.ja: その出版社では、入館の際に身分証明書を提示しなければなりません。

meaning_mnemonic: If 出版 means <kanji>publishing</kanji>, then a <kanji>company</kanji> that does said publishing is a <vocabulary>publishing company</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Will help to know the word 出版 as well, though.

examples.en: You think you’re so great, but bear in mind, you are just a poor person from a poor family!
examples.ja: お前は自分のことを素晴らしいと思っているみたいだけどな、ただの貧乏家族の貧乏人だってことを、よ〜く肝に銘じておくんだな。

meaning_mnemonic: 貧乏 is <kanji>poor</kanji>, so a poor <kanji>person</kanji> is a <vocabulary>poor person</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Will help to know 貧乏 already.

examples.en: I’m really sensitive to the cold, especially my feet which are always cold.
examples.ja: 私は冷え性で、特に足がいつも冷えています。

meaning_mnemonic: If 冷やす is "to chill something," then this would be the version where something is just chilled. You're not doing the action of chilling anything, it's just that way. You know this because if you get involved, there's always some kind of chilling <reading>err</reading>or (える). So, you step back and let the fridge do its job without messing.
reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from 冷やす. Know that and you know this as well.

examples.en: You’ve gotta stop thinking about your ex-girlfriend, especially because you asked Salmon’s dad if you could marry her and he said yes.
examples.ja: お前、もう元カノについて考えるのはよした方がいいぞ。特に、サーモンのお父さんに彼女と結婚していいかどうか聞いて、許しも得ちまったんだからな。

meaning_mnemonic: 結婚 is <kanji>marriage</kanji>, so the verb version of that would be <vocabulary>to marry</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to get married</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. It will help to know 結婚 first, though.

examples.en: At this kindergarten, photography and filming are prohibited during the student recital.
examples.ja: この幼稚園では、子どもたちの発表会は撮影禁止です。

meaning_mnemonic: 撮影 is <kanji>photography</kanji>. 禁止 is <kanji>prohibition</kanji>. So if photography is prohibited, then we can assume there's a <vocabulary>no photos</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>no photos allowed</vocabulary> rule in place.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Will help to know the words 撮影 and 禁止.

examples.en: "Have you got everything, Koichi?" "Yes, mom." "Oh, wait. I forgot to put the teriyaki salmon in your bento box." "What! Hurry, mom!"
examples.ja: 「コウイチ、忘れ物は無い？」「無いよ。」「あ、ちょっと待って。あんたのお弁当に照り焼きサーモン入れるの忘れてたわ。」「ええっ！母さん、早くしてよ。」

meaning_mnemonic: You <kanji>illuminate</kanji> some food, then <kanji>bake</kanji> it. To illuminate it, you put on some shiny sauce. Sound familiar, in terms of a type of food? This is <vocabulary>teriyaki</vocabulary>, though I have to warn you it's quite different from the teriyaki you get in the west.
reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from 照る and 焼く. Put them together and you have something delicious.

examples.en: I want to know how to get rid of the acne on my back.
examples.ja: 背中のニキビを無くす方法が知りたいよ。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>middle</kanji> of your <kanji>back</kanji> is <vocabulary>one's back</vocabulary> (or your <vocabulary>back</vocabulary>).
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the kun'yomi readings, put together, making it the words 背 and 中 combined.

examples.en: It’s worth subscribing to this magazine.
examples.ja: その雑誌は購読する価値がありますよ。

meaning_mnemonic:
If 購読 is a "subscription", then the verb vocab version would be <vocabulary>to subscribe</vocabulary>.

Reminder: this refers specifically to paying for a subscription to reading materials, like newspapers or magazines, so avoid using it for free subscriptions or music apps!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Oh, it's already late. I have to go pick up the kids.
examples.ja: あ、もうこんな時間。子供を迎えに行かなくちゃ。

examples.en: We'll run today's show with three top LDP officials.
examples.ja: 今日の番組は、自民党三役を迎えてお送りいたします。

examples.en: We are thinking of welcoming a puppy into our home, but which kind can be easily trained not to bark unnecessarily?
examples.ja: うちに仔犬を迎えたいなと思ってるんですが、無駄吠え防止の訓練をしやすいのは何犬でしょうか。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji means <kanji>welcome</kanji>, but the verb version is <vocabulary>to pick someone up</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to meet someone</vocabulary>. That's weird. But, think of it this way: When you go to welcome someone, you are going <vocabulary>to meet someone</vocabulary> too. You have to go somewhere to wait and welcome them, which is why you are going to pick someone up or going to meet them. Something like that anyways.
reading_mnemonic: <vocabulary>To pick someone up</vocabulary> you are going to drive your <reading>moo ca</reading>r. It's a car that's designed to look like a cow, but you think it will be a nice way to welcome your friend.

examples.en: An escaped gorilla caused a major scene in some country, didn't it?
examples.ja: どこかの国で、ゴリラが逃げ出して大騒ぎになっていたことがあったよね。

meaning_mnemonic: If 騒ぐ is "to make noise," then a <kanji>big</kanji> version of this is even louder. It's a <vocabulary>clamor</vocabulary> and an <vocabulary>uproar</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is word that uses the kun'yomi readings of the kanji, which you should know already because 大 is pretty familiar to you by now (I hope) and you just learned 騒ぐ as well! Put them together, with a little tweaking at the end, and you have your reading. Ta-da!

examples.en: I usually skip a book’s preface.
examples.ja: 私はいつも本の序文は飛ばします。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Preface</kanji> <kanji>writing</kanji> is the <vocabulary>preface</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: After I successfully bid on Yahoo auctions, I wrote about the order of procedures on my blog.
examples.ja: ヤフオクで入札した後の手続きの順序についてブログでまとめてみました。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>order</kanji> of things is the <kanji>preface</kanji> to the entire <vocabulary>sequence</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>steps</vocabulary> we're planning on taking. So, just remember. The order is just the preface. It is what allows us to come up with a sequence.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I hope you will grow up with big ambitions.
examples.ja: 志の大きい子に育ってくれよ。

examples.en: I have decided to live a life of rich ambitions.
examples.ja: 志豊かに生きていこうと決心しました。

examples.en: Viet has high aspirations and is steadily making his dreams come true.
examples.ja: ビエトは高い志を持っており、どんどん夢を実現していってる。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic: When you have the <vocabulary>ambition</vocabulary> to do something, it feels like you're pointing at it with your heart. To say "heart pointing" in Japanese, you could say <reading>心ざし</reading> (こころざし), which is how this word was written in classical Japanese. In modern Japanese it's always 志, but the reading is exactly the same. Now get out there and heart point to your dreams!

examples.en: I’m aware that I’m a weak-willed person.
examples.ja: 自分が意志の弱い人間だってことは自覚してますよ。

meaning_mnemonic: You have an <kanji>idea</kanji> and you have <kanji>intent</kanji> to carry it out. This is your <vocabulary>will</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>volition</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: What is your motivation for applying for this job?
examples.ja: この仕事を志望する動機は何ですか？

meaning_mnemonic: Your <kanji>intention</kanji> for your <kanji>hope</kanji> is what you want. It's not just a hope. You have intention behind it. This is your <vocabulary>desire</vocabulary>. This is your <vocabulary>ambition</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Koichi is my benefactor. He rescued me when I got addicted to bacon.
examples.ja: コウイチは私の恩人です。私がベーコンに溺れていた時、私を救ってくれたんです。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>kindness</kanji> <kanji>person</kanji> is a very kind person. This person is a <vocabulary>benefactor</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I'll give a reward to the person who can catch the bacon thief.
examples.ja: あのベーコン泥棒を引っ捕えた者には恩賞を与えよう。

examples.en: Please keep in mind that rewards will be assigned proportionate to your work.
examples.ja: 功労に準じて恩賞が付与されるということを覚えておいてくださいね。

examples.en: Emperor Godaigo's Kenmu Restoration had a bad reputation from samurai because court nobles got far more rewards than samurai did.
examples.ja: 後醍醐天皇による建武の新政は、公家にはたくさん恩賞が出たのに武士には少なかったため、武士からの評判が悪かった。

meaning_mnemonic:
A <kanji>kindness</kanji> <kanji>prize</kanji> is one that someone gives you out of kindness. Perhaps you've done something nice, which is why they are giving you a <vocabulary>reward</vocabulary>.

Note: this is an older word, so you'll probably only see it in history books, but it's important to know anyway!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: My daddy is good at catching beetles.
examples.ja: 僕のお父さんはカブト虫を採る名人です。

meaning_mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>gather</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to gather</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: When you gather things, you go around and take things from their original location to put them together in your gathering spot. In Japanese, when you take something, you could say 取る, right? This word has the same reading: <reading>とる</reading>.

examples.en: The teacher was having trouble deciding which textbook to use.
examples.ja: 教師はどの教科書を採用するかを迷っていた。

examples.en: Apparently that chocolate maker adopted "Just wait, chocolate!" as its new slogan.
examples.ja: あのチョコレートメーカーが「ちょっと待てチョコラテ！」という新しいスローガンを採用したそうです。

examples.en: As is often the case, they say that company only employs attractive women.
examples.ja: よくあるように、その会社は女性は顔で採用するそうですよ。

meaning_mnemonic: I <kanji>gather</kanji> things and <kanji>use</kanji> them. The things I've gathered, are the things I <vocabulary>use</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: OK, let’s take a vote. Who wants Fugu-nabe for dinner?
examples.ja: じゃあ、多数決で採決しよう。夕食にてっちり（ふぐ鍋）が食べたい人は？

meaning_mnemonic: When people <kanji>gather</kanji> and <kanji>decide</kanji> things, they decide together, usually by <vocabulary>voting</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: If we found gold on another planet, took it back to Earth and sold it, would we make a profit?
examples.ja: もし別の惑星で金を見つけることができて、それを地球に持ち帰って販売した場合、採算は取れるのでしょうか。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Gather</kanji> the money and then <kanji>calculate</kanji> how much of it you have. Oh, nice, looks like you have a <vocabulary>profit</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: A person who entices or lures another person is called decoy in English, sakura in Japanese, and troll on the internet.
examples.ja: 相手の気を引いたりうまく釣ったりする人のことを英語ではデコイと言うが、日本語では桜、ネット用語では釣りと言う。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji.

examples.en: These cherries are ridiculously tasty.
examples.ja: この桜んぼ、やばいくらい美味しいんだけど。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>cherry tree</kanji> can create a <vocabulary>cherry</vocabulary>. This is what this word is.
reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from the kanji.

examples.en: You should come with me to the horse meat party. It’s going to be hip.
examples.ja: お前も一緒に桜肉パーティーに来いよ。イカしたパーティーになるぜ。

meaning_mnemonic: Strangely, <kanji>cherry tree</kanji> <kanji>meat</kanji> isn't just some kind of cherry steak... it's <vocabulary>horse meat</vocabulary>. Hopefully you'll just remember that due to the strangeness of this word's kanji.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the words 桜 and 肉 put together into one horse steak of a word.

examples.en: I saw a picture of me in a full-fledged pink tux when I was two or three years old.
examples.ja: 自分が二歳か三歳の頃に、一丁前に桜色のタキシードを着てる写真を見ました。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>cherry blossom</kanji> <kanji>color</kanji> is what color? Kind of a <vocabulary>pink</vocabulary>, wouldn't you say? Also, pink can be ピンク, if you want it to be.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the readings for 桜 and 色 combined.

examples.en: Waiting for the kitchen timer to go off feels like forever, doesn't it?
examples.ja: キッチンタイマーが鳴るのを待つのって、かなり永遠な感じがするよね。

examples.en: Won't you ever come back to Japan again?
examples.ja: もう永遠に日本には帰ってこないの？

examples.en: A witch's magic has brought eternal winter to this country, but she's been permanently sealed in that pot. Unless we release the witch, we can't bring the four seasons back.
examples.ja: ある魔女の魔法で、この国には永遠の冬がもたらされたんだけど、魔女はその鍋に永遠に封印されていてね。魔女を解き放たない限りは、四季は取り戻せないんだ。

meaning_mnemonic: An <kanji>eternity</kanji> that is <kanji>far</kanji> away is not really an eternity, it just feels like it. It's <vocabulary>forever</vocabulary>, but not the real kind of forever that's actually forever. That's 永久, which is a real forever, this is more like "whoa, I haven't eaten sushi in forever" (actually, you have).
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I’ve removed my armpit hair permanently, so my armpits are very smooth now.
examples.ja: 脇毛を永久脱毛したから、今脇はツルツルだよ。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Eternity</kanji> is a <kanji>long time</kanji>... as in <vocabulary>forever</vocabulary>. This word has to do with an actual forever. So, like, forever. Not like an "oh man I haven't done that in forever," because if you've done something before, it's not forever. This is forever for realsies.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: How much liquid can I bring onto a plane?
examples.ja: 機内に持ち込み可能な液体の量はどれぐらいですか。

meaning_mnemonic: Things that have a <kanji>fluid</kanji> <kanji>body</kanji> are made of <vocabulary>liquid</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Why is blood red?
examples.ja: どうして血液は赤いのですか。

meaning_mnemonic: Your <kanji>blood</kanji> <kanji>fluid</kanji> is your <vocabulary>blood</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Using computers to work can easily overwork your eyes.
examples.ja: コンピュータを使う仕事は眼を酷使しやすい。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. This is just a little more technical than 目.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as the word "eye" (目), so use that to remember this!

examples.en: I searched high and low for my left eyeball, but I just couldn’t find it.
examples.ja: 私は自分の左の眼球をあちこち捜したが、なかなか見つけられなかった。

meaning_mnemonic: An <kanji>eyeball</kanji> <kanji>sphere</kanji> is an <vocabulary>eyeball</vocabulary>. Eww.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: When does age-related farsightedness usually start?
examples.ja: 老眼は大体いつ頃から始まるんですか。

meaning_mnemonic: An <kanji>elderly</kanji> <kanji>eyeball</kanji> is one that can't see things close up. That's why this word means <vocabulary>farsightedness</vocabulary>. But this is the kind of farsightedness that only comes with age. So you have to be an elderly oldey to have 老眼.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Our family has a special diaper that has been passed down from father to son for six generations.
examples.ja: うちの家族には、六世代に渡って先祖代々受け継がれてきた特別なおむつがあります。

meaning_mnemonic: Your <kanji>previous</kanji> <kanji>ancestor</kanji>s are your <vocabulary>ancestors</vocabulary>. All ancestors are previous to you, after all, unless you want to talk time travel, then who knows.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Just remember there is a rendaku that changes そ to ぞ！

examples.en: Hmm, how can I put this? My grandfather is just a moody guy. Sometimes he's in a good mood, sometimes he's in a bad mood. So don't worry about it too much.
examples.ja: う〜ん、何て言ったらいいのかな。僕の祖父は単なる気分屋なんだよね。機嫌がいい時もあれば、悪い時もあるっていうか。だから、あんまり気にしないで。

meaning_mnemonic: Your <kanji>ancestor</kanji> <kanji>father</kanji> isn't your father, it's the father that came before your father's generation, your <vocabulary>grandfather</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is all on'yomi, which is great for 祖 but not as great for 父. To remember that this 父 is ふ, just think about how much of a <reading>foo</reading>l (ふ) your grandfather was, even if he wasn't.

examples.en: My grandmother always has flashy jewelry on her fingers.
examples.ja: 私の祖母はいつも指にド派手な指輪を嵌めています。

meaning_mnemonic: Your <kanji>ancestor</kanji> <kanji>mother</kanji> isn't your mother, it's the mother before your mother, your <vocabulary>grandmother</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading for 祖 is known to you, but the 母 part is not. To remember the on'yomi reading for 母 in 祖母, just think about how your <vocabulary>grandmother</vocabulary> had a <reading>bo</reading>at (ぼ), even if she didn't... and what an amazing boat it was. If you want, you can imagine your grandma is a boat too, but that might not be very nice.

examples.en: It’s difficult to decide who deserves credit for success.
examples.ja: 成功が誰の功績かを判断するのは難しい。

meaning_mnemonic:
One <kanji>achievement</kanji> plus another <kanji>achievement</kanji> is an even bigger <vocabulary>achievement</vocabulary>. Wow, what an <vocabulary>accomplishment</vocabulary>!

功績 is a formal word that refers to noteworthy contributions or successes. It's commonly used to praise someone's hard work or great results.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: My grades have gotten a lot better thanks to my personal tutor.

meaning_mnemonic: What kind of things <kanji>become</kanji> your <kanji>achievement</kanji>s? Your <vocabulary>grades</vocabulary>. At least when you're in school, that is. Your grades become your main achievements, right? So let's take a look at those grades… Oof, some of those "achievements" weren't all that amazing. Don't worry, grades aren't everything.

examples.en: I’m pretending that I have no interest in hentai games.

examples.en: As the dental hygienist told me to open my mouth I saw a flash of white teeth from her tanned face.
examples.ja: その歯科衛生士は、お口を開けてください、と私に言いながらにやりと笑い、日焼けした顔に白い歯をキラリと見せた。

meaning_mnemonic: In <kanji>defense</kanji> of <kanji>life</kanji>, you have to remain clean. If you are dirty, you will die earlier (think: plagues). So, to defend said life, you must have good <vocabulary>hygiene</vocabulary>.

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>defense</kanji> <kanji>star</kanji> isn't really a star, but it is something shiny in the sky that can look like a star if it's bright enough. This is a <vocabulary>satellite</vocabulary>, and while it's not always defensive, satellites can have defensive properties. Think ion cannons and deflector shields and things like that.

examples.en: I have multiple nicknames and accounts.

examples.en: You can keep the original, but we’ll take a copy.
examples.ja: 一枚目はお手元にお持ちください。私達は複写の方を頂きますね。

meaning_mnemonic:
When you make a <kanji>duplicate</kanji> <kanji>copy</kanji> you are <vocabulary>copying</vocabulary> things. Especially if you're making a <vocabulary>photocopy</vocabulary> or a <vocabulary>carbon copy</vocabulary>. It's like a copy of a copy! 

複写 is a pretty formal word for copying documents, text, or images. It's still often used to talk about carbon copies. But for photocopies, most people just say コピー(する) these days.

examples.en: I want to get rid of the static in this sound file.
examples.ja: この音声ファイルの雑音を消したいんです。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Random</kanji> <kanji>noise</kanji> is still <vocabulary>noise</vocabulary>, though more specifically it is random noise, like <vocabulary>static</vocabulary>.

examples.en: What is the average cost of a Japanese college student’s food and miscellaneous expenses?
examples.ja: 日本の大学生の食費と雑費の平均はいくらぐらいですか。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Random</kanji> <kanji>expense</kanji>s are <vocabulary>miscellaneous expenses</vocabulary>. Not actually random, but they feel that way.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. The ざつ goes to ざっ and the ひ goes to ぴ, making it into a dumb sounding word, like "zappy" (ざっぴ), so you can think about how some of your miscellaneous expenses were on zappy items.

examples.en: The first food I ate was rotten and sour.
examples.ja: 最初に食べた食べ物は腐りかけていて酸っぱかったです。

meaning_mnemonic: The taste of something with <kanji>acid</kanji> is... well... you'd think it'd be acidic, but it's a <vocabulary>sour</vocabulary> taste. Some acidic things are pretty sour, though. Lemons are pretty acidic, and they're super sour too, so think about that when you need to remember this word.
reading_mnemonic: Something was so <vocabulary>sour</vocabulary> that it broke your mouth. You were so upset about this, that you decided to <reading>sue</reading> (す) the maker of this nasty sour thing.

examples.en: Do you support Japan accepting new immigrants?
examples.ja: 日本が新たな移民を受け入れることには賛成ですか。

meaning_mnemonic: It has <kanji>become</kanji> that we <kanji>agree</kanji>. We have <vocabulary>agreement</vocabulary>!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I do aerobic exercises every afternoon.
examples.ja: 毎日午後に有酸素運動をしています。

meaning_mnemonic:
The <kanji>acid</kanji> <kanji>element</kanji> is <vocabulary>oxygen</vocabulary>. In German it’s the same as in Japanese - it’s called “Sauerstoff”, including “sauer”, the word for “sour”. The noun version is “Säure” which means both “sourness” and “acid” (which again is the same in Japanese, the same kanji is used in both words). The word “oxygenium” in Greek/Latin literally means “acid maker”. Long ago chemists thought oxygen was a defining characteristic of acids, later they found out there are also acids without oxygen like hydrochloric/muriatic/salt acid and the defining characteristic actually is hydrogen. But the name stuck.

Or you could just imagine all the oxygen you breathe has turned into acid (oh no!), and it sucks to breathe. Whatever works for you.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Ms. Sakurada is always told that she is greedy for money by Mr. Nakagawa.
examples.ja: 桜田さんは中川さんからいつも銭ゲバって言われています。

examples.en: That Viet guy always finds a good way to make a buck. I'd like to learn how to make a few bucks.
examples.ja: ビエトのやつ、いつもいいシノギを見つけてくるよな。ちょっと銭のかせぎ方を教えてもらいたいよ。

examples.en: I'm just a slave who will work until I die to earn money for my wife.
examples.ja: 私は妻のために死ぬまで働いて銭を稼ぐだけの奴隷ですよ。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well. It can also mean <vocabulary>money</vocabulary> more generally.
reading_mnemonic: The reading for the kanji is せん, the reading for this vocab word is <reading>ぜに</reading>. They're pretty similar, but only ぜに rhymes with "penny."

examples.en: My grandfather starts his day by going to a public bath.
examples.ja: 祖父の一日は、銭湯から始まります。

meaning_mnemonic: Give a <kanji>coin</kanji> and get <kanji>hot water</kanji>. So you hand over a coin and then you get hot water in the form of a bath. It's a bath for anyone willing to pay, making it a <vocabulary>public bath</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You don't know the on'yomi reading of 湯, though, so just think about how when you get in the <vocabulary>public bath</vocabulary>, you're in <reading>To</reading>kyo (とう), because there are a lot of public baths in Japan, and Tokyo is the most well known city there.

examples.en: I want to keep some reptiles as pets.
examples.ja: 何か爬虫類をペットに飼いたいな。

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji is <kanji>domesticate</kanji>. When you domesticate an animal, you get <vocabulary>to keep a pet</vocabulary> of some kind. You'd use this to describe when you are keeping a dog or cat or something.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the one you learned with the kanji. The か of <reading>ca</reading>t!

examples.en: How dare you damage my reputation? I'll never forgive you!

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.

examples.en: He dumped me and I’m a little heartbroken, so I’m going on a trip to Paris to get over it.

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>wound</kanji> of your <kanji>heart</kanji>. That could be many things, but in this case it's <vocabulary>heartbreak</vocabulary>.

The translation doesn't really get hinted at in this meaning, but this group is the <vocabulary>Liberal Democratic Party</vocabulary>, aka the <vocabulary>LDP</vocabulary>.

examples.en: I eat eggs every morning.
examples.ja: 私は卵を毎朝食べています。

examples.en: Today, I boiled eggs and put them in a salad.
examples.ja: 今日は卵をゆでてサラダに入れました。

examples.en: But I'm still bad at cracking eggs.
examples.ja: でも、まだ卵を割るのが苦手です。

examples.en: The proverb "Don't count your chickens before they hatch" is "Don't count your pelts before you've caught the tanuki" in Japanese.
examples.ja: 「卵がかえる前にひなを数えるな」ということわざは、日本語では「とらぬタヌキの皮算用をするな」です。

examples.en: "Do you have raw egg allergy?" "Not that I know of."
examples.ja: 「生卵アレルギーはありますか？」「私の知る限りではありません。」

meaning_mnemonic: Remember how 生 can mean <kanji>raw</kanji>? Well, it does now. So, a <kanji>raw</kanji> <kanji>egg</kanji>? First of all, delicious. Second of all, it means <vocabulary>raw egg</vocabulary>.

examples.en: If you think I stole your boiled egg, you’re barking up the wrong tree.

meaning_mnemonic: The ゆで comes from the verb ゆでる, which means "to boil." So this word means <vocabulary>boiled egg</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from the kanji.

examples.en: Many people write harsh comments on the internet.
examples.ja: インターネットでは厳しいコメントを書く人が多い。

meaning_mnemonic: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of <kanji>strict</kanji>? It is also <vocabulary>strict</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The most <vocabulary>strict</vocabulary> creature in Japan is the <reading>key bee</reading> (きび). Little key bees have to be very strict about locking the doors to their hive. If they aren't strict enough, the scary Japanese hornets will get in and kill them all. Have you seen those things? They're terrifying!

examples.en: Private conversations with coworkers are strictly prohibited.
examples.ja: 従業員同士の私語は厳禁です。

meaning_mnemonic: Something with <kanji>strict</kanji> <kanji>prohibition</kanji> is <vocabulary>strictly forbidden</vocabulary> / <vocabulary>strictly prohibited</vocabulary>.

examples.en: My husband throws away food that’s past its freshness date, even if it was only by one day.
examples.ja: 私の主人は、たとえ一日でも賞味期限が過ぎていたら捨てるんですよ。

meaning_mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>throw away</kanji> so the verb version is <vocabulary>to throw away</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the one you learned with the kanji, so no need <vocabulary>to throw away</vocabulary> that bit of knowledge just yet!

examples.en: Jumping into the pool is prohibited here.
examples.ja: ここではプールに飛び込むのは禁止です。

examples.en: The man restrained the robber with both hands.
examples.ja: 男は強盗を両手で押さえ込みました。

examples.en: Satomi was lost in thought for a while.
examples.ja: サトミはしばらく考え込んでいました。

meaning_mnemonic:
This word ends with the hiragana う, which tells you it's a verb. The kanji 込 means <kanji>into</kanji>, so the verb version is <vocabulary>to get into</vocabulary>.

This word generally attaches to the stem of another verb, and adds a nuance of moving something towards the center of something, or going deep into something. You’ll be seeing lots of examples of words with 込む on the end, so you’ll gradually get a feel for the nuance it adds!
reading_mnemonic: Lucky for you, the reading you learned with the kanji is the one you use here.

examples.en: We entered the family registry in secret, without even letting the whole family know.
examples.ja: 僕たちは、お互いの家族にも知らせず、密かに入籍をしたんだ。

meaning_mnemonic: Something that has <kanji>secrecy</kanji> is <vocabulary>secret</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>private</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: Think about that really <vocabulary>secret</vocabulary> and <vocabulary>private</vocabulary> dude. <reading>He so</reading> (ひそ) secret...

examples.en: We often make use of this room for secret meetings.
examples.ja: 私達は密会によくこの部屋を利用しています。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>secrecy</kanji> <kanji>meet</kanji> is a <vocabulary>secret meeting</vocabulary>. You know the password?
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. Note that みつ changes to みっ.

examples.en: In every era, there are people who try to curry favor with their bosses and get ahead by snitching on others.
examples.ja: いつの時代でも、密告をすることで上司に取り入って、出世をねらう人間がいます。

examples.en: The informant's testimony revealed the full scope of the case.
examples.ja: 密告者の証言で、事件の全容が明らかになった。

examples.en: During the war, there was a system in place for neighbors to inform on each other.
examples.ja: 戦時中には、ご近所同士の密告制度がありました。

examples.en: I'd like to inform the tax office about a certain company's tax evasion.
examples.ja: とある会社の脱税について、税務署に密告したいと思ってるんです。

meaning_mnemonic:
In <kanji>secrecy</kanji>, you <kanji>announce</kanji> something to the authorities. Why? Because you are giving them a <vocabulary>tip-off</vocabulary>. The person you're <vocabulary>informing</vocabulary> on might even say you're <vocabulary>snitching</vocabulary>.

密告 means secretly informing on someone — usually about wrongdoing or a crime — to the authorities or a person in charge. It carries a strong negative tone, often suggesting betrayal or sneaky behavior, like reporting a fellow gang member's drug possession to the police.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. The みつ goes to みっ.

examples.en: Your secret is safe with me. My lips are sealed.
examples.ja: 秘密は誰にも言わないよ。ちゃんと、口にチャックしておくよ。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Secret</kanji> and <kanji>secrecy</kanji>. Combine the two and you have quite the <vocabulary>secret</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I was asked to smuggle narcotics once.  Of course I refused.
examples.ja: 俺は一度麻薬の密輸をする話を持ちかけられたことがあるよ。もちろん断ったけどね。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>secrecy</kanji> <kanji>transport</kanji> is when you transport something in secrecy. If you don't want people to know what you're transporting, you'll have to resort to <vocabulary>smuggling</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I’m wondering what color to dye my hair.
examples.ja: 髪を何色に染めるか迷っています。

meaning_mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>dye</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to dye</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: You need <vocabulary>to dye</vocabulary> something that you just <reading>sew</reading>ed (そ) together. It's all sewed and looks like a shirt, but it's colorless. That's where the dying comes in.

examples.en: I didn’t know that periodontitis is a type of infectious disease.
examples.ja: 歯周病は感染症の一種だとは知りませんでした。

meaning_mnemonic: The <kanji>feeling</kanji> of <kanji>dye</kanji>, covering your body, is the feeling of nasty germs and diseases penetrating your skin, getting inside of you. This is an <vocabulary>infection</vocabulary>, and it's gross.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: What is the most dangerous infectious disease in the world?
examples.ja: 世界で一番危険な伝染病は何ですか。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>sick</kanji>ness that can <kanji>transmit</kanji> and then <kanji>dye</kanji> into you (aka get inside you and infect you, via transmission) is a <vocabulary>contagious disease</vocabulary>. Everyone cover their mouths when they cough and sneeze, and please wash your hands, okay?
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I don’t recommend white controllers because they get dirty easily.
examples.ja: 汚れやすいので白いコントローラーはお勧めしません。

examples.en: You can remove blood stains from linen and clothing by washing them right away in hydrogen peroxide.
examples.ja: 血で汚れたシーツや服は、すぐにオキシドールで洗えば綺麗になるよ。

examples.en: Didn't you know? Defiled angels can't stay in the heavenly realm.
examples.ja: 知らないの？汚れた天使は、もう天界にはいられないんだよ。

meaning_mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>dirty</kanji> so the verb vocab version is <vocabulary>to get dirty</vocabulary>. You know you're not doing the dirtying, because it's <reading>rare</reading> (れる) for you to get anything dirty, though things do get dirty on their own.
reading_mnemonic:
Things seem <vocabulary>to get dirty</vocabulary> easily around here, which is why <reading>you go</reading> (よご) to great lengths to keep things clean.

Note that the reading よごれる is generally used for getting physically dirty, whereas けがれる is more figurative, so more like “to be defiled”.

examples.en: How can I find out about PM2.5 contamination levels in my community?
examples.ja: 自国のPM2.5汚染レベルはどうすれば分かるのでしょうか。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>dirty</kanji> <kanji>dye</kanji> that's all throughout the sky and makes things gross when it touches them is <vocabulary>pollution</vocabulary>. If it's bad enough it really is like a dye, too, making your white clothes brown, yuck.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Sewage pipes get blocked on snow days.
examples.ja: 雪の日に汚水の配管が詰まってしまいました。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Dirty</kanji> <kanji>water</kanji> is <vocabulary>dirty water</vocabulary>. Gross. Could also be <vocabulary>sewage</vocabulary>. Even grosser.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: A disgrace in life is also called dark history in Japanese.
examples.ja: 人生の汚点は日本語では黒歴史とも呼ばれる。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>dirty</kanji> <kanji>point</kanji> is a little point of dirtiness on something. This is a <vocabulary>stain</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>smudge</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: "You can buy anything you want. Money is no limit." "Wow! Do you have a fever? What’s up with you?"
examples.ja: 「欲しいものを買っていいよ。金額の制限は無しだよ。」「まあ！熱でもあるの？ 何かあったの？」

meaning_mnemonic: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of <kanji>want</kanji>? It's also <vocabulary>wanted</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: What do you want? A <reading>hoe</reading> (ほ), like a garden hoe, you sicko.

examples.en: I can't satisfy my ramen craving with cup noodles.
examples.ja: カップラーメンでは、私のラーメン欲求をみたすことは出来ません。

examples.en: Humans have pride and a desire to be recognized for their worth.
examples.ja: 人間にはプライドがあり、自分の価値を認められたいという欲求がある。

examples.en: My wife is constantly frustrated.
examples.ja: 私の妻は、頻繁に欲求不満になります。

meaning_mnemonic: What you <kanji>want</kanji> and <kanji>request</kanji> are your <vocabulary>wants</vocabulary>, your <vocabulary>desires</vocabulary>, perhaps your <vocabulary>craving</vocabulary>. You want these things so you request them. I wants them!
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. よく goes to よっ, so be careful not to want the wrong reading.

examples.en: Why do some Christians and Buddhists deny their carnal desires like they’re something sinful?
examples.ja: どうしてキリスト教徒と仏教徒の中には、肉欲を罪深いものだとして否定する人がいるのですか。

meaning_mnemonic: Your <kanji>meat</kanji> <kanji>want</kanji>s are your deepest desires, your <vocabulary>carnal desires</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: I want to go on a diet, but I have too much of an appetite.
examples.ja: ダイエットをしたいんですが、食欲があり過ぎるんですよね。

meaning_mnemonic: I have a <kanji>food</kanji> <kanji>want</kanji>. When I want food (or when I don't want food), it has to do with your <vocabulary>appetite</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: It was a nice warm day today.
examples.ja: 今日はポカポカと暖かい一日だった。

meaning_mnemonic: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of <kanji>warm</kanji>? It's <vocabulary>warm</vocabulary> as well! Though this is for a <vocabulary>warm</vocabulary> weather or temperature, not some warm food or something like that, that would be 温かい, a different あたたかい. Confusing, right?
reading_mnemonic:
The reading is the same as 温かい, which also means <vocabulary>warm</vocabulary>. But while that 温かい refers to a warm thing, this 暖かい refers to a warm temperature or place.

Just like with 温かい, people often pronounce this as あったかい in conversation. But when it comes to kanji exams or typing out the kanji, remember to use あたたかい!

examples.en: This winter is unusually cold and we have had tons of snow, so is the earth really getting warmer?
examples.ja: 今年の冬は例年よりも寒くて雪も凄く降ったけど、本当に地球は温暖化してるのかね。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Warm</kanji> <kanji>warm</kanji> is <vocabulary>warm</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: "I put the picture of Koichi on your desk." "Thanks. I owe you one."
examples.ja: 「君の机の上に、コウイチの写真を置いておいたよ。」「ありがとう。恩に着るよ。」

meaning_mnemonic: The kanji and the word are exactly the same. That means they share meanings as well.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as what you learned with the kanji.

examples.en: I’m worried about him because he tends to hide his feelings.
examples.ja: 彼は内に秘めるタイプなので、心配しています。

meaning_mnemonic: If you <kanji>secret</kanji> something, you are trying <vocabulary>to keep secret</vocabulary> something. That, or you're trying <vocabulary>to conceal</vocabulary> it.
reading_mnemonic: The reading is the same as the one you learned with the kanji, strangely enough. Nothing <vocabulary>to conceal</vocabulary> about this reading, you gots it.

examples.en: I’ve been constipated. I haven’t pooped in a week!
examples.ja: 便秘がひどくてさぁ。もう一週間以上ウンコしていないんだよ！

meaning_mnemonic: For this word, the 便 comes from 便所, which you know as "toilet." A <kanji>toilet</kanji> <kanji>secret</kanji> is one you take with you to the bathroom, one that you don't want people to know about. This is <vocabulary>constipation</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own. The ひ changes to ぴ because "P" stands for "Poop."

examples.en: Can you tell me the reason why you tried doing a handstand over the toilet?
examples.ja: どうして便器の上で逆立ちをしようとしたのか訳を聞かせてください。

meaning_mnemonic:
This word takes the <kanji>reason</kanji> meaning of the kanji, making it <vocabulary>reason</vocabulary>. What's the reason for it having two meanings? I have no clue, but there must be a reason.

While 理由 is the general term for reasons, 訳 tends to be more focused on the underlying reason or cause of something. It's also used when explaining a situation or when there's an implied need to justify or clarify something.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word is made up of a single kanji, it probably uses the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn this reading, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

What's your <vocabulary>reason</vocabulary> to <reading>wake</reading> (わけ) up this morning? Think about it. Now think of your reason to wake up tomorrow. What is it?

examples.en: This word is difficult to translate.
examples.ja: この単語を訳すのは難しい。

meaning_mnemonic: Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>translate</kanji> so the verb version would be <vocabulary>to translate</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading for the kanji part is surprisingly the やく you learned with it, even you wouldn't expect that. I suppose that's the kind of thing you have to look forward to if you were to go into translating.

examples.en: Do you know how to read the name of this book’s translator?
examples.ja: この本の訳者の名前、何て読むか知ってる？

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>Someone</kanji> who <kanji>translate</kanji>s things is a <vocabulary>translator</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: For some Japanese words, there are no good English equivalents.
examples.ja: 日本語の中には、良い英語の訳語が無い時がある。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>translate</kanji>d bit of <kanji>language</kanji> is a <vocabulary>translated term</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: If I were omnipotent, I would be able to interpret this conversation for you, but I’m not, so I can’t. Sorry.
examples.ja: もし私が全能の神だったら、この会話を通訳してあげることができるけど、そうじゃないから無理だわ。ごめんよ。

meaning_mnemonic: If you let words <kanji>pass through</kanji> you, and as they do you <kanji>translate</kanji> them, you are doing <vocabulary>interpreting</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: All I can do is to translate from Japanese to English.
examples.ja: 日本語から英訳することしかできません。

meaning_mnemonic: <kanji>English</kanji> <kanji>translate</kanji> is an <vocabulary>English translation</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Aside from some minor mistakes, I think your Japanese translation was pretty good.
examples.ja: いくつか小さな間違いはあるものの、うまく和訳できていると思いますよ。

meaning_mnemonic: Remember how 和 represents Japan? Now, take that and add <kanji>translate</kanji> to it. With that, you have <vocabulary>Japanese translation</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Do you know where I should go to extend my visa?
examples.ja: ビザを延長するにはどこに行ったらいいのか知ってる？

meaning_mnemonic: If 延長 is <kanji>prolonging</kanji>, then the verb version is <vocabulary>to prolong</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: Even adults can have accidents and wet themselves.
examples.ja: 大人でも、おしっこを漏らすことはありますよ。

examples.en: Please don't let this secret slip out.
examples.ja: この秘密は、絶対に漏らさないでくださいね！

examples.en: My mother turned away and quietly let out a sigh.
examples.ja: 母は、後ろを向いた後、静かにため息を漏らした。

examples.en: I wonder if someone leaked the information?
examples.ja: 誰かが情報を漏らしたんじゃない？

meaning_mnemonic:
You learned 漏れる means "to leak." 漏らす is the transitive version, which means it takes a direct object. So this means <vocabulary>to let something leak</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>to leak something</vocabulary>. The reason you let something leak is because you <reading>rush</reading>ed (らす) the job (because you did it yourself)!

Even though it's transitive, 漏らす often implies an unintentional leak, as in おしっこを漏らす (wet one's pants) or 水を漏らすな (don't let water spill). It's also used figuratively, like 秘密を漏らす (leak a secret), 不満を漏らす (express dissatisfaction), or ためいきを漏らす (let out a sigh).
reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from 漏れる, so if you know that, you know this! Don't let that memory leak from your head.

examples.en: How can I be taller than 6.5 feet like NBA players? I’m 6 feet now and I want to go beyond 6.5.
examples.ja: どうすればNBA選手のように身長が6.5フィートを越すのでしょうか。今、6フィートなのですが、6.5を越したいのです。

meaning_mnemonic:
Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>go beyond</kanji> so the verb vocab version is also <vocabulary>to go beyond</vocabulary>.

This is very similar in meaning to 越える. Both can refer to overcoming some physical object or passing beyond a certain amount of time. However, 越す tends to sound a little less intense, while 越える really focuses on the physical or emotional challenge of overcoming a certain milestone. For example, while 山を越す simply refers to crossing a mountain, 山を越える gives the impression that crossing the mountain is a difficulty you've overcome.
reading_mnemonic:
The reading is the same as 越える. So if you know that you know this too! In case you need a reminder, here's the mnemonic:

<vocabulary>To go beyond</vocabulary> <reading>child</reading> (こ) years in order to become an adult, you have to be 18 years old in the USA, and 20 years old in Japan.

examples.en: Many people get too carried away by the olympics.
examples.ja: たくさんの人がオリンピックに浮かれすぎている。

meaning_mnemonic: 浮く means "to float," and 浮かれる draws on that metaphor of "floating" to mean <vocabulary>to be happy</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to be in high spirits</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>to be elated</vocabulary>. We have the same metaphor in English — think of being "on cloud nine."
reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from 浮く, so if you know that you' are going <vocabulary>to be happy</vocabulary> and you won't have a <reading>care</reading> (かれる) in the world!

examples.en: Glasses suit Koichi better than contact lenses.
examples.ja: コウイチにはコンタクトよりもメガネが似合います。

examples.en: I think a denim jacket would totally go with that dress.
examples.ja: そのワンピには絶対デニムのジャケットが似合うと思うよ。

examples.en: Unfortunately, it's not always the case that one's favorite color will suit one.
examples.ja: 残念ながら、自分の好きな色が必ずしも自分に似合うとは限らないのよね。

meaning_mnemonic: It <kanji>resemble</kanji>s you! It <kanji>suit</kanji>s you! Wow, your good looks really cause this scarf <vocabulary>to suit</vocabulary> you, you know?
reading_mnemonic: The reading is from 似る and 合う, put together.

examples.en: A short guy staggered out of the bar and threw up in front of me.
examples.ja: 背丈の低い男が千鳥足でバーから出てきて、私の目の前でゲロを吐いたんです。

meaning_mnemonic: Someone's <kanji>back</kanji> <kanji>height</kanji> is their <vocabulary>height</vocabulary>. It also refers to their <vocabulary>stature</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: The reading comes from the vocab readings of 背 and 丈, combined together.

examples.en: I spilled curry and got a burn on my hand.
examples.ja: カレーを零して、手に火傷を負った。

meaning_mnemonic: A <kanji>fire</kanji> <kanji>wound</kanji> is a <vocabulary>burn</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>scald</vocabulary> you got from fire (or other hot things). Ouch!
reading_mnemonic: The reading for this is unlike anything you've seen with these kanji. Try to think about a <vocabulary>burn</vocabulary> (on your arm) being caused by a <reading>yakky do</reading>do (やけど) bird (which is a dodo bird that has yak-like features). Take a look at how weird it is, and wonder why it is burning you. Feel the pain.

examples.en: I showed the will to win a gold medal.
examples.ja: 金メダル獲得に意欲をみせた。

meaning_mnemonic: If you have an <kanji>idea</kanji> of what you <kanji>want</kanji> already, then that's good! You have <vocabulary>will</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>desire</vocabulary>, and <vocabulary>ambition</vocabulary>. Those who don't know what they want can't have any of these.
reading_mnemonic: This is a jukugo word that uses the on'yomi readings of the kanji. You should be able to read this on your own.

examples.en: My mother is the scariest in the world.
examples.ja: 俺の母親は世界で一番恐い。

meaning_mnemonic: This is a single kanji with an い on the end, meaning you know it's probably an adjective. What's the adjective form of <kanji>fear</kanji>? <vocabulary>Scary</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>frightening</vocabulary>. It can also mean <vocabulary>I'm afraid</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>I'm scared </vocabulary> too.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You didn't learn that reading with this kanji, so here's a mnemonic to help you: 

You know what's really scary? <reading>Koa</reading>las (こわ). Have you ever heard one of those things? They're super scary, don't go near them.

examples.en: I’ve never seen such a tall hobbit before.
examples.ja: こんなに背が高いホビットは見たことがないよ。

meaning_mnemonic: This is the words 背 and 高い put together to make one adjective. When your height is tall it means you are a <vocabulary>tall</vocabulary> person. This word is only used for tall people though, not anything else that's tall like a building or a tree.
reading_mnemonic: This word is actually two separate words combined with a particle. So, since you treat them like separate words, you read each of them with the kun'yomi readings (they are both single kanji words all alone). You've learned both of these readings before now, so you should be able to read this word already!

examples.en: It's about time we started preparations for the New Year’s decorations.
examples.ja: そろそろ正月飾りの準備をしておかなくちゃ。

meaning_mnemonic: This is the noun version of the kanji <kanji>decorate</kanji>, so it means <vocabulary>decoration</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading already so you should be able to read it!

examples.en: She’s a really plain woman.
examples.ja: あいつは本当に飾り気のない女だ。

meaning_mnemonic: If you <kanji>decorate</kanji> your <kanji>spirit</kanji> with a bunch of pretty things like streamers and balloons, people will think you're just <vocabulary>showing off</vocabulary>. Yes, you know your spirit is awesome, but everyone else doesn't want it pushed in their face with your over the top decorations.
reading_mnemonic:
Since the first part of this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You've learned how to read the かざ part already with the 飾る vocabulary.

The second kanji uses the on'yomi reading. You didn't learn this reading for 気 yet, so here's a mnemonic to help you:

At the height of <vocabulary>showing off</vocabulary>, you bend one arm to your hip and the other out in the air. You pretend to be a <reading>ke</reading>ttle (け). You show off your spirit to all your friends singing "I'm a little ke-ttle, short and stout. Here is my handle, here is my spout. EVERYONE LOOK HOW GREAT I AM!" Your kettle dance is sure to impress them.

examples.en: Please tell me about the popular games in schools nowadays.
examples.ja: 最近学校で流行っている遊びを教えて下さい。

examples.en: I started playing the piano just for fun, but before I knew it, I had become a professional.
examples.ja: ピアノは遊びで始めたんですが、気づいたらプロになってました。

examples.en: He's a genius when it comes to play and always comes up with fun things to do.
examples.ja: 彼は遊びに関しては天才で、いつも面白いことを思いつきます。

examples.en: Her playful designs are loved by many people.
examples.ja: 彼女の遊び心あふれるデザインは、多くの人に愛されています。

examples.en: That affair wasn't serious; I was just playing around. Really, believe me!
examples.ja: あの浮気は、本気じゃなくてただの遊びだったんだ。本当だよ、信じてくれよ！

meaning_mnemonic: This is the noun version of the kanji <kanji>play</kanji>, so it means <vocabulary>play</vocabulary> or <vocabulary>playing</vocabulary>!
reading_mnemonic: You learned this reading when you learned 遊ぶ. It's the same one!

examples.en: My body feels hot from this high fever.
examples.ja: 高熱で体が火照っています。

meaning_mnemonic: If <kanji>fire</kanji> <kanji>illuminate</kanji>s your face, you're going <vocabulary>to feel hot</vocabulary>. Sometimes you start <vocabulary>to flush</vocabulary> when you're embarrassed and it just feels like there is fire making your face light up.
reading_mnemonic:
The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You haven't learned this reading for 火 yet, but it's easier to remember this with a mnemonic for the whole thing:

When are you going <vocabulary>to feel hot</vocabulary>? When is your face going <vocabulary>to flush</vocabulary>? When I ask you to go to a <reading>hotel</reading> (ほてる) with me!

examples.en: I lost a button from my suit.
examples.ja: 背広のボタンをなくした。

examples.en: I always send my suit to the cleaners.
examples.ja: 背広はいつもクリーニングに出します。

examples.en: I'm wearing my new business suit today because I have an important meeting.
examples.ja: 今日は重要な会議があるので、新しい背広を着ていきます。

examples.en: I had a new business suit tailored for the upcoming formal marriage interview.
examples.ja: 今度のお見合いのために新しく背広を新調しました。

meaning_mnemonic: If your <kanji>back</kanji> is <kanji>wide</kanji>, you need a nice <vocabulary>business suit</vocabulary> to cover it up when you go to work. Otherwise you'll look completely out of place sitting at a desk like a giant, wide-backed wrestler. Is that what you want to look like? Of course not! You need to go out and buy a fancy suit to cover your wide back up right now!
reading_mnemonic: The readings for this word are both kun'yomi readings. You've learned them both already so you should be able to read this too! Just watch out for the weird rendaku here making it び not ひ.

examples.en: Do you like the smell of leather jackets, senpai?
examples.ja: 先輩、革ジャンの匂いは好きですか？

examples.en: That hot spring smells like banana.
examples.ja: その温泉は、バナナの匂いがする。

examples.en: The odor of this bathroom is so strong that I don't want to breathe through my nose.
examples.ja: このトイレは匂いが強すぎて、鼻で息をしたくない。

meaning_mnemonic:
This the noun version of the kanji for <kanji>smell</kanji>. It also means <vocabulary>smell</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>scent</vocabulary>!

Although 匂う often implies something smells unpleasant, 匂い is more neutral and can refer to any kind of smell.
reading_mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading with the kanji, so you should be able to read it already!

examples.en: Oh geez. Even my tail got wet in the rain.
examples.ja: やれやれ。雨で尻尾まで濡れちゃったよ。

examples.en: My iPhone is waterproof, so it doesn't get wet even if I take a bath with it.
examples.ja: 私のiPhoneはウォータープルーフだから、一緒にお風呂に入っても濡れないの。

examples.en: Your hair is still wet. You should dry it before you go to sleep.
examples.ja: あなた、髪がまだ濡れているわよ。乾かしてから、寝なさい。

meaning_mnemonic: This word consists of kanji with hiragana attached. Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>wet</kanji>, so the verb version is <vocabulary>to get wet</vocabulary>.
reading_mnemonic: Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this reading with the kanji, so you should be able to read it already!

examples.en: It's been decided I'll take care of my sister's child on Sunday.
examples.ja: 日曜日に妹の子供を預かることになった。

examples.en: The job of a bank isn't only to take care of money.
examples.ja: 銀行の仕事はお金を預かるだけではありません。

examples.en: I want you to hold onto this for me in case I need it.
examples.ja: 必要になった時のために預かっておいてほしい。

meaning_mnemonic:
Because the hiragana ends with an う sound, you know this word is a verb. The kanji itself means <kanji>deposit</kanji>, and this word is for when someone is depositing something (or someone) with you, because they want you <vocabulary>to look after</vocabulary>, <vocabulary>to take care of</vocabulary>, or <vocabulary>to hold on to</vocabulary> it.

Remember that 預ける is used when you leave something with someone else to take care of temporarily. 預かる, on the other hand, is used when you're the one receiving something to look after. You can remember this because you're great at taking care of cargo (かる). You're always looking after everyone's cargo, but you're happy to hold on to it for them.

Also note that even though 預かる ends with かる and kind of looks intransitive, it's actually an exception! It'll pretty much always have a direct object to specify what you're looking after.
reading_mnemonic:
Since this word consists of a kanji with hiragana attached, you can bet that it will use the kun'yomi reading. You learned this before with the pair verb 預ける, but here's a mnemonic to remind you just in case:

You need someone <vocabulary>to look after</vocabulary> your kids for the day. Hey, I have an idea! Leave them with the monkeys at <reading>a zoo</reading> (あず)! Monkeys love kids, and kids love monkeys. Now you can zoom off in your <reading>car</reading>s (か) for the day!
